elements.content: The reaction of 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) with Zn(NO3)2·6H2O or Co(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of NH4PF6 in water−methanol or water−acetone produced both {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n (1) or {[CoL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n (2). The metal ions in both complexes coordinate with six identical N atoms from six different ligands in an ideal octahedral environment where each ligand binds to two metal ions. Both complexes are one-dimensional triple-helical chains each containing an empty lotus-root-structured polymetallocage. The metallocage in 1 is fully empty, while the cage in 2 contains two water molecules. However, metallocages in 1 have a void volume of ∼200 Å3, which is much smaller than the 1020 Å3 void in 2. The void in 2 is comparable to the size of fluorescein. Both complexes are capable of encapsulating fluorescein anion in pH 9 aqueous solution to form {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ML3]} n , where C20H10O5 2− is fluorescein dianion, and M is Zn or Co. The encapsulation occurs via anion exchange. The cages in 1 are increased drastically to fit the size of fluorescein due to the flexibility of ligand, while in 2 the cages have no discernible change after fluorescein encapsulation due to a perfect match between the cavity size in 2 and the fluorescein. Fluorescein encapsulated 1 and 2 have identical powder X-ray diffraction patterns, indicating that they have similar structures after fluorescein encapsulation. Both complexes show fluorescence after fluorescein encapsulation.

elements.content:
4,4′-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl reaction with Zn(II) or Cu(II) salt produces polymetallocage polymers. The metallocages can effectively encapsulate guest fluorescein dianions.

Introduction

The designed construction of coordination polymers from soluble molecular building blocks represents one of the most challenging issues facing synthetic chemistry today. Porous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) are important coordination polymers and have attracted widespread interest in the past decade because of their fascinating structures and intriguing potential applications. Recent studies have shown the great potential of coordination framework compounds for gas storage, particularly for hydrogen and methane. Rigid aromatic carboxylates are the most used building blocks to construct coordination frameworks as they have a strong coordination ability to transition metal ions and versatile coordination modes. Of the aromatic carboxylates, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate are studied most extensively. Besides these rigid aromatic carboxylates, flexible ligands were also used to construct functional coordination polymers, such as bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (bimb) (Scheme ). 4,4′-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) is quite similar structurally to bimb. The only paper published of the ligand is one reporting an unusual polyoxometalate-encapsulating three-dimensional (3D) polyrotaxane framework formed by molecular squares threading on a 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid skeleton [CuIIL2(H2O)2][CuI 2L2]PMo12O40.

4,4'-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl reaction with Zn(II) or Cu(II) salt produces polymetallocage polymers. The metallocages can effectively encapsulate guest fluorescein dianions.

Introduction

The designed construction of coordination polymers from soluble molecular building blocks represents one of the most challenging issues facing synthetic chemistry today. Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are important coordination polymers and have attracted widespread interest in the past decade because of their fascinating structures and intriguing potential applications. Recent studies have shown the great potential of coordination framework compounds for gas storage, particularly for hydrogen and methane. Rigid aromatic carboxylates are the most used building blocks to construct coordination frameworks as they have a strong coordination ability to transition metal ions and versatile coordination modes. Of the aromatic carboxylates, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate are studied most extensively. Besides these rigid aromatic carboxylates, flexible ligands were also used to construct functional coordination polymers, such as bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) and 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (bimb) (Scheme ). 4,4'-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) is quite similar structurally to bimb. The only paper published of the ligand is one reporting an unusual polyoxometalate-encapsulating three-dimensional (3D) polyrotaxane framework formed by molecular squares threading on a 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid skeleton [CuIIL2(H2O)2][CuI 2L2]PMo12O40.

elements.content: On the other hand, coordination-driven self-assembly has been widely used in the construction of novel nanosized supramolecular objects due to their novel structures and properties. An enormous body of work has been published since the 1960s on topics such as helicates, cages, catenanes, rotaxanes, and triple-helix. Research demonstrates that control by coordination number and charge can stimulate the self-assembly of different heterodinuclear triple-stranded helicates.

An enormous body of work has been published since the 1960s on topics such as helicates, cages, catenanes, rotaxanes, and triple-helix. Research demonstrates that control by coordination number and charge can stimulate the self-assembly of different heterodinuclear triple-stranded helicates.

elements.content: In the early days of research in the field of MOFs, it was believed that rigidity of the host network was a prerequisite for their successful performance as porous materials, because it was assumed that flexibility would lead to a collapse of the structure. This perspective has changed fundamentally. The discovery of a series of flexible porous coordination frameworks demonstrated that some MOF materials can change their void volumes significantly (some of them by up to 40% or even 170%) while preserving their basic structures.
elements.clean_text: In the early days of research in the field of MOFs, it was believed that rigidity of the host network was a prerequisite for their successful performance as porous materials, because it was assumed that flexibility would lead to a collapse of the structure. This perspective has changed fundamentally. The discovery of a series of flexible porous coordination frameworks demonstrated that some MOF materials can change their void volumes significantly (some of them by up to 40% or even 170%) while preserving their basic structures.

elements.content: Our own recent work has focused on the design and synthesis of a wide range of new MOF materials that show unusual and unique topologies and structure. Our work indicates that {[Co(H2O)6]·[Co3L′2(H2O)2]·10H2O} n , where L′ is a 4,4′-bipyridyl-2,2′,6,6′-tetracarboxylate anion, can absorb a considerable amount of methanol or ethanol. We report herein the synthesis, structure, and fluorescein adsorption properties of triple-helix, lotus-root like polymetallocage complexes assembled from 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) and zinc(II) or cobalt(II). Interestingly, both complexes are composed of triple-helical metallocages. The cage sizes are similar in length but differ greatly in width. These triple-helical metallocages are large enough to accommodate nanosize molecules. We choose fluorescein as a guest molecule because the cage size matches the size of fluorescein perfectly. Fluorescein is colored and has strong fluorescence that is easy to characterize. The wider one matches the size of fluorescein perfectly, while the smaller one increases its cage size considerably (5 times) to accommodate fluorescein. To our knowledge, this is the most significant void change up to now.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Ligand 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) was synthesized according to the literature. Disodium salt of fluorescein was prepared according to the literature. Elemental analyses were determined using a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000−400 cm−1 region using KBr pellets and a Nicolet AVATAR-370 spectrometer. Metal contents were analyzed on a iCAP 6300 (Thermo-Fisher) atomic emission spectrometer. Excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer using a slit width of 3.0 nm for excitation and 3.0 nm emissions at room temperature for the solid samples. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis data were collected on a Netzsch STA-409PC under air in the temperature range from 20 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/max-2550 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatic CuKa (1.54056 Å) radiation at 40 kV/250 mA at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Ligand 4,4'-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (L) was synthesized according to the literature. Disodium salt of fluorescein was prepared according to the literature. Elemental analyses were determined using a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 region using KBr pellets and a Nicolet AVATAR-370 spectrometer. Metal contents were analyzed on a iCAP 6300 (Thermo-Fisher) atomic emission spectrometer. Excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer using a slit width of 3.0 nm for excitation and 3.0 nm emissions at room temperature for the solid samples. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis data were collected on a Netzsch STA-409PC under air in the temperature range from 20 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/max-2550 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatic CuKa (1.54056 Å) radiation at 40 kV/250 mA at room temperature.

elements.content: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of water. This solution was added to a 10 mL methanol solution containing L (31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 10 min and then filtered. The filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week. Colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. We washed the crystal with water and methanol. Yield: 67% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Zn: C, 48.39; H, 3.91; N, 18.81. Found: C, 48.44; H, 3.69; N, 18.93. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1501(m), 1440(m), 1278(s), 1210(m), 1123(s), 1020(m), 988(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 766(m), 678(m), 659(m), 557(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n  (1)

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (30.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of water. This solution was added to a 10 mL methanol solution containing L (31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 10 min and then filtered. The filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week. Colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. We washed the crystal with water and methanol. Yield: 67% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Zn: C, 48.39; H, 3.91; N, 18.81. Found: C, 48.44; H, 3.69; N, 18.93. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3440(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1501(m), 1440(m), 1278(s), 1210(m), 1123(s), 1020(m), 988(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 766(m), 678(m), 659(m), 557(m).

elements.content: An 8-mL aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were placed on the bottom of a glass tube. Five milliliters of 1:1 (V/V) acetone−water was carefully layered on top of the aqueous solution. Finally, 8 mL of acetone solution (contains 31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol of ligand) was layered. We carefully sealed the glass tube. Red-block crystal settled gradually after a month, and then it was filtered and washed with water and acetone. Yield: 46% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Co: C, 48.62; H, 3.93; N, 18.90. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.73; N, 18.96. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3438(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1499(m), 1440(m), 1277(s), 1210(m), 1121(s), 1022(m), 989(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 769(m), 679(m), 659(m), 557(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[CoL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n  (2)

An 8-mL aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were placed on the bottom of a glass tube. Five milliliters of 1:1 (V/V) acetone-water was carefully layered on top of the aqueous solution. Finally, 8 mL of acetone solution (contains 31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol of ligand) was layered. We carefully sealed the glass tube. Red-block crystal settled gradually after a month, and then it was filtered and washed with water and acetone. Yield: 46% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Co: C, 48.62; H, 3.93; N, 18.90. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.73; N, 18.96. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3438(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1499(m), 1440(m), 1277(s), 1210(m), 1121(s), 1022(m), 989(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 769(m), 679(m), 659(m), 557(m).

elements.content: Fluorescein encapsulations were investigated for samples before drying and after full vacuum dehydration at 120 °C overnight, respectively. Thus, 160 mg of fluorescein was suspended in 10 mL of water, 1 mol·L−1 KOH was added carefully to increase pH to 9 to dissolve fluorescein, corresponding to 0.05 mmol·L−1 fluorescein disodium. A crystal of 1 or 2 (∼200 mg) was added to the above solution and the mixture was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week with occasional shaking or stirring. The sample was filtrated off and washed with water and methanol. From weight gains, the encapsulations were estimated. {[ZnL3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n : C, 66.09; H, 4.35; N, 18.75. Found: C, 65.78; H, 4.49; N, 18.53. Calcd. Zn, 4.86%. Found: Zn, 4.97%. {[Co(L)3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n : C, 66.41; H, 4.37; N, 18.84. Found: C, 65.93; H, 4.45; N, 18.65. Calcd. Co, 4.37%. Found: Co, 4.43%.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorocein Encapsulation

Fluorescein encapsulations were investigated for samples before drying and after full vacuum dehydration at 120 °C overnight, respectively. Thus, 160 mg of fluorescein was suspended in 10 mL of water, 1 mol⋅L-1 KOH was added carefully to increase pH to 9 to dissolve fluorescein, corresponding to 0.05 mmol⋅L-1 fluorescein disodium. A crystal of 1 or 2 (~200 mg) was added to the above solution and the mixture was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week with occasional shaking or stirring. The sample was filtrated off and washed with water and methanol. From weight gains, the encapsulations were estimated. {[ZnL3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n : C, 66.09; H, 4.35; N, 18.75. Found: C, 65.78; H, 4.49; N, 18.53. Calcd. Zn, 4.86%. Found: Zn, 4.97%. {[Co(L)3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n : C, 66.41; H, 4.37; N, 18.84. Found: C, 65.93; H, 4.45; N, 18.65. Calcd. Co, 4.37%. Found: Co, 4.43%.

elements.content: Well-shaped single crystals of 1 and 2 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. Data collections were performed with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct method with SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their calculated position. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Well-shaped single crystals of 1 and 2 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. Data collections were performed with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct method with SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their calculated position. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description of 1 

Crystal structure analysis gives 1 the formula of {[Zn(L)3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n . The formula agrees well with elemental analysis and thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) analysis. The TG curve of the complex indicates that the complex framework is stable up to 265 °C. The 2.65% weight loss corresponds to two crystalline water molecules (2.69%) (). The IR spectrum shows a strong characteristic of PF6 - at 840 cm-1 (Figure ).

elements.content: In 1, it is clear that the repeat unit contains one [ZnL3]2+ cation, two hexafluophosphate anions, and two crystal water molecules. Central Zn(II) is coordinated to six ligands in an ideal octahedral environment (σ = 1.0) (Figure ). The formula is similar to that of complex {[Mn(bimb)3](ClO4)2(H2O)2} n reported by Fei et al. where bimb is 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-biphenyl. Different from that in {[Mn(bimb)3](ClO4)2(H2O)2} n , the ligand in complex 1 is central-symmetric with a torsion angle of 28.0(4)° between the two benzene rings, while the benzene and adjacent triazole is almost perpendicular with a dihedral angle of 84.13°. The two triazoles have a dihedral angle of 20.96(1)° (). In the triazole moiety, only N1 coordinated to metal ion. The distance of Zn(1)−N(1) is 2.184(2) Å, which is somewhat shorter than Mn−N distances of 2.25 Å in {[Mn(bimb)3](ClO4)2(H2O)2} n . The distance of two adjacent Zn in the triple helical chain is 16.821(3) Å, which is quite similar to that of Mn−Mn distances of 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-biphenyl complex 16.96 Å. While in the oxacalix[2]arene[2]pyrazine silver polycage complex, the two silver atoms are separated by 12.669 Å. The two terminal triazole groups are in opposite directions with reference to the average biphenyl plane and serve to link two adjacent Zn ions. As a result, three ligands and two Zn form a lotus-root-like triple-helical cage and two adjacent cages that share a Zn atom and such units form an infinite one-dimensional chain. This is similar to that of 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-biphenyl Mn(II) complex. The inside of the lotus-root-like triple-helical chain is fully empty. Figure b is the view from the c-axis. As shown in Figure b, each lotus-root-like chain is surrounded by PF6 − anions. The triple-helical chains are well separated from each other by PF6 − anions. The crystalline water molecules are located outside the cage between the PF6 − anions from the c-axis (Figures S3 and b).

elements.content: The formula of complex 2 is identical to 1 except there are Co(II) instead of Zn(II). TG analysis indicates there are two water molecules in the complex (). Water molecules in 2 are somewhat more stable than that in 1 because of water losses at higher temperature. This probably due to the two crystalline water molecules are inside the cavity of 2 (). The coordination environment, bond angles, and distances are also similar to that in 1 (Figure ). Co−N distances in 2 (2.172(3) Å) are slightly shorter than Zn−N distances (2.184(2) Å) in 1, indicating that ligands coordinate to Co(II) ions more readily than to Zn(II). However, the Co···Co distances in the triple-helical cage 2 is 15.809(2) Å, which is obviously shorter than the Zn···Zn distance 16.821(3) Å in 1. The lotus-root cage is obviously wider than that in 1. The shortest C7···C7 distance between two ligands within a cage in 1 is 4.586 Å, while this distance increased to 8.403 Å in Co complex 2. Taking van der Waals radii into account, the cavity size in 2 is 13 Å long with a diameter of 10 Å cylinders, corresponding to a cavity volume of 1020 Å3. The cage cavity in 1 is 14 Å long with a diameter of 5.6 Å cylinder, corresponding to a cavity volume of only 220 Å3. This can also be observed from the calculated density of the crystals. The density of 1 is 1.556 g·cm−3, while 2 is 1.322 g·cm−3. This lower density is an indication of a larger cavity size. From the crystal structure, the C3 atom that binds to triazole are away from the cavity in 2, while in 1, the C3 atoms are toward the cavity. This made the cavity in 2 much larger than that in 1. The two benzene rings in a ligand have a dihedral angle of 140.85(1)°, which is significantly larger than 28.0(4)° found in 1. Benzene and adjacent triazole have a dihedral angle of 122.48°. The two triazoles have a dihedral angle of 45.893(4)°. These are comparable with that in complex 1. From the c-axis, the cage in 2 is much wider than that in 1 ().

Structure Description of 2 

The formula of complex 2 is identical to 1 except there are Co(II) instead of Zn(II). TG analysis indicates there are two water molecules in the complex (). Water molecules in 2 are somewhat more stable than that in 1 because of water losses at higher temperature. This probably due to the two crystalline water molecules are inside the cavity of 2 (). The coordination environment, bond angles, and distances are also similar to that in 1 (Figure ). Co-N distances in 2 (2.172(3) Å) are slightly shorter than Zn-N distances (2.184(2) Å) in 1, indicating that ligands coordinate to Co(II) ions more readily than to Zn(II). However, the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances in the triple-helical cage 2 is 15.809(2) Å, which is obviously shorter than the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance 16.821(3) Å in 1. The lotus-root cage is obviously wider than that in 1. The shortest C7⋅⋅⋅C7 distance between two ligands within a cage in 1 is 4.586 Å, while this distance increased to 8.403 Å in Co complex 2. Taking van der Waals radii into account, the cavity size in 2 is 13 Å long with a diameter of 10 Å cylinders, corresponding to a cavity volume of 1020 Å3. The cage cavity in 1 is 14 Å long with a diameter of 5.6 Å cylinder, corresponding to a cavity volume of only 220 Å3. This can also be observed from the calculated density of the crystals. The density of 1 is 1.556 g⋅cm-3, while 2 is 1.322 g⋅cm-3. This lower density is an indication of a larger cavity size. From the crystal structure, the C3 atom that binds to triazole are away from the cavity in 2, while in 1, the C3 atoms are toward the cavity. This made the cavity in 2 much larger than that in 1. The two benzene rings in a ligand have a dihedral angle of 140.85(1)°, which is significantly larger than 28.0(4)° found in 1. Benzene and adjacent triazole have a dihedral angle of 122.48°. The two triazoles have a dihedral angle of 45.893(4)°. These are comparable with that in complex 1. From the c-axis, the cage in 2 is much wider than that in 1 ().

elements.content: As the lotus-root-like cages are empty within a hydrophobic environment, the void is a 13 Å long round cylinder with a diameter of 8 Å. The cavity size can adjust to accommodate guest molecules because the ligand is flexible. The crystal structure of fluorescein indicates that it is a molecule with a size of 10 × 7 × 6 Å, and this size matches the cavity of the triple-helical cage. Since fluorescein is an aromatic molecule, we expect that the triple-helical cage is capable of encapsulating fluorescein molecules not only with matching size, but also with hydrophobic interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescein Encapsulation

As the lotus-root-like cages are empty within a hydrophobic environment, the void is a 13 Å long round cylinder with a diameter of 8 Å. The cavity size can adjust to accommodate guest molecules because the ligand is flexible. The crystal structure of fluorescein indicates that it is a molecule with a size of 10 × 7 × 6 Å, and this size matches the cavity of the triple-helical cage. Since fluorescein is an aromatic molecule, we expect that the triple-helical cage is capable of encapsulating fluorescein molecules not only with matching size, but also with hydrophobic interaction.

elements.content: In fact, the neutral lactonoid form and the colored quinonoid forms (univalent and bivalent anions) are in equilibrium in an aqueous solution of fluorescein. Scheme illustrates the different forms of fluorescein at different pH values. In pH 9 aqueous solution, the predominant species is the dianion form. Among the different forms, the bivalent anion form exhibited the most intense fluorescence. Complex 1, either as-synthesized or vacuum-dried sample, can encapsulate fluorescein in pH 9 aqueous solutions. Figure is the monograph of the synthesized complex, fluorescein encapsulated complex under room light and under UV light. The encapsulation is also observable by weight gains after immersing the sample in solution for some time. The weight increased 2.70−3.00% after fluorescein encapsulation. IR spectra of the complexes before encapsulation reveal characteristics of PF6 − anion at 840 cm−1 (Figure ). After encapsulation of fluorescein anion, the 840 cm−1 peak significantly decreases, and the 1124 and 557 cm−1 bands shifted closer to the position of the free ligand (Figure ). This indicates that the encapsulation is an anion exchange process. From an electronic view, each fluorescein dianion replaces two PF6 − anions. Fully replacing all PF6 − with fluorescein dianions will increase the weight (3.0%) of the sample. This agrees well with the weight increase after the introduction of fluorescein. Similar phenomena happened for complex 2. IR spectra indicate PF6 − disappeared after fluorescein encapsulation (). The weight also increased 3.20% after fluorescein encapsulation. All these signs indicate that the fluorescein encapsulation is similar in 1 and 2 and is an anion exchange process. Elemental analysis and iCAP metal ion analysis agree well with the formula of {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n or {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n for complex 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: PXRD of complex 1 indicate the crystallinity keeps well before and after drying and fluorescein encapsulation (Figure ). Drying significantly changes the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is quite common, but also quite different from that of the Co(II) complex (Figure ). The PXRD patterns of fluorescein encapsulated samples are similar whether 1 is vacuum-dried overnight or as-synthesized without any drying. The most intense absorption at 21.4° in 1 was shifted to a smaller 21.3°, while the intensity of weak peak at 20.6° was increased significantly after drying. A peak at 17.6° appeared after drying. After fluorescein encapsulation, the strongest peak shifted to 19.3°. These data indicate that crystal 1 changes its configuration after encapsulation of fluorescein.

PXRD Pattern

The PXRD patterns of fluorescein encapsulated samples are similar whether 1 is vacuum-dried overnight or as-synthesized without any drying. The most intense absorption at 21.4° in 1 was shifted to a smaller 21.3°, while the intensity of weak peak at 20.6° was increased significantly after drying. A peak at 17.6° appeared after drying. After fluorescein encapsulation, the strongest peak shifted to 19.3°. These data indicate that crystal 1 changes its configuration after encapsulation of fluorescein.

elements.content: For complex 2, hydration does not significantly change its PXRD pattern (Figure ). Fluorescein encapsulation slightly changes the PXRD pattern, but the strongest peak was at 19.3°, without any changes before and after encapsulation. Interestingly, complexes 1 and 2 have quite different PXRD patterns. However, fluorescein encapsulated samples have almost identical PXRD patterns (). This indicates that fluorescein was encapsulated in the cavity of the cage that shrinks Zn···Zn distances from 16.821(3) Å in free 1 to ∼15.8 Å after encapsulating fluorescein. Cages in 2 are large enough to accommodate guest fluorescein. Scheme is the schematic representation of the fluorescein encapsulation process. During the encapsulation process, cage in 1 increases its cavity size drastically to the size of the cage in 2 (5 times) to fit the size of guest fluorescein dianions (). This is reasonable because the ligand is somewhat flexible. The drastic void volume change induced by host−guest interaction in MOFs has been reported. The literature reported drastic void volume increase of 170% for a three-dimensional MOF. Complex 1 increases the void volume 5 times after encapsulation of fluorescein dianion. To our knowledge, this is the most drastic void volume increase. Several reasons cause the striking void increase without collapse of the structure. First of all, the ligand is quite flexible, and slight rotation of the triazole ring will significantly increase the width of the cavity without significantly changing the length of the void. In fact, complexes 1 and 2 have a similar structure and cell parameters; the smaller void in 1 is because the biphenyl group is in the lower side close to Zn, while in 2, these biphenyl groups are in the upper side away from Co. This causes the void in 2 to be much wider than that in 1. In the c-axis, the lotus-root-like chains are well separated by PF6 − anions (), while in complex 2, the cavities are wider that they are very close each other, while the PF6 − fills the cavity joints (). Scheme illustrates the encapsulation (void increase) process. Fluorescein dianion was encapsulated inside the cavity not just outside the cavity. The reason is that complex 2 has a cavity size that matches the size of fluorescein; its PXRD pattern has no significant changes before and after encapsulation, while the PXRD pattern for 1 changes significantly. {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n and {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n have identical PXRD patterns which indicates that the cavity size in free 1 increased drastically (5 times) to the size similar to that in 2. To our knowledge, complex 1 is the most adaptable complex to date.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , ligand and complex 1 both have an ∼430 emission peak when excited at 360 nm. The fluorescein encapsulated sample has a strong emission of 554 nm under identical experimental conditions. Free fluorescein dianion has a fluorescence peak at 514 nm (Figure ), which is identical to reported data in the solid state. We attribute the 554 nm fluorescence to fluorescein. The significant red-shift can be attributed the biphenyl moiety. The biphenyl moiety may have π−π interactions with the aromatic rings of fluorescein dianion which will decrease the energy level of fluorescein dianion. Complex 2 is paramagnetic and has no fluorescence as expected. After fluorescein adsorption, it has fluorescence emissions at 465 nm when excited at 435 nm (). The significant fluorescence difference between 1 and 2 is attributed to the paramagnetism and diamagnetism of metal ions. In UV light, {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n displays a bright color ().
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectra

As shown in Figure , ligand and complex 1 both have an ~430 emission peak when excited at 360 nm. The fluorescein encapsulated sample has a strong emission of 554 nm under identical experimental conditions. Free fluorescein dianion has a fluorescence peak at 514 nm (Figure ), which is identical to reported data in the solid state. We attribute the 554 nm fluorescence to fluorescein. The significant red-shift can be attributed the biphenyl moiety. The biphenyl moiety may have π-π interactions with the aromatic rings of fluorescein dianion which will decrease the energy level of fluorescein dianion. Complex 2 is paramagnetic and has no fluorescence as expected. After fluorescein adsorption, it has fluorescence emissions at 465 nm when excited at 435 nm (). The significant fluorescence difference between 1 and 2 is attributed to the paramagnetism and diamagnetism of metal ions. In UV light, {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n  displays a bright color ().

elements.content: TG and DSC curve of the fluorescein encapsulated sample differs greatly from the as-synthesized complex (Figures and ). Whether dried or not, the fluorescein encapsulated sample show no water molecules. The strong exothermic peak at 175 °C is possibly phase transfer due to no observable weight loss. This phenomena was also observed in Al2O3/fluorescein sodium salt in which fluorescein sodium salt crystallizes on the surface of Al2O3 which gives a endothermic peak. {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n (1) and fully dried {[ZnL3](PF6)2} n give identical TG/DSC after encapsulation, and this indicates that the crystalline water in 1 does not affect the encapsulation. This data agree well with the PXRD and IR result. All data indicate that water molecules in complex 1 do not affect fluorecein encapsulation. The TG/DSC curve of fluorescein encapsulated 2 is similar to that of complex 1 (Figure ). The IR spectra of the fluorescein encapsulated sample is quite similar to that of the free ligand, but the product is not a free ligand. Elemental analysis and iCAP metal analysis data are consistent with the formula {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n and/or {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n . Second, the solubility indicates that the product is not a free ligand because it cannot dissolve in methanol/ethanol. Third, the existence of strong fluorescence at 554 nm, which is absent in free ligand, also indicates that the sample is not a free ligand but contains fluorescein.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Gravity

TG and DSC curve of the fluorescein encapsulated sample differs greatly from the as-synthesized complex (Figures  and ). Whether dried or not, the fluorescein encapsulated sample show no water molecules. The strong exothermic peak at 175 °C is possibly phase transfer due to no observable weight loss. This phenomena was also observed in Al2O3/fluorescein sodium salt in which fluorescein sodium salt crystallizes on the surface of Al2O3 which gives a endothermic peak. {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n  (1) and fully dried {[ZnL3](PF6)2} n  give identical TG/DSC after encapsulation, and this indicates that the crystalline water in 1 does not affect the encapsulation. This data agree well with the PXRD and IR result. All data indicate that water molecules in complex 1 do not affect fluorecein encapsulation. The TG/DSC curve of fluorescein encapsulated 2 is similar to that of complex 1 (Figure ). The IR spectra of the fluorescein encapsulated sample is quite similar to that of the free ligand, but the product is not a free ligand. Elemental analysis and iCAP metal analysis data are consistent with the formula {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n  and/or {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n . Second, the solubility indicates that the product is not a free ligand because it cannot dissolve in methanol/ethanol. Third, the existence of strong fluorescence at 554 nm, which is absent in free ligand, also indicates that the sample is not a free ligand but contains fluorescein.

elements.content: 4,4′-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl coordinate to Zn(II) and Co(II) bidentately to form {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n and {[CoL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n , respectively. Both complexes are 1D triple helical coordination polymers composed of metallocages. The cage in 2 is much wider than that in 1. The cage is fully empty in 1. The cage in 2 contains two water molecules. The void size in 2 matches the size of fluorescein perfectly. Both complexes can encapsulate fluorescein dianion which replace the hexafluorophosphate anion. Regarding fluorescein encapsulation, the cage in 1 increases its void size drastically (5 times) to fit the size of fluorescein, while the cages in 2 have no discernible changes after fluorescein encapsulation. This can be explained by size match between host metallocage and guest fluorescein.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

4,4'-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl coordinate to Zn(II) and Co(II) bidentately to form {[ZnL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n  and {[CoL3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n , respectively. Both complexes are 1D triple helical coordination polymers composed of metallocages. The cage in 2 is much wider than that in 1. The cage is fully empty in 1. The cage in 2 contains two water molecules. The void size in 2 matches the size of fluorescein perfectly. Both complexes can encapsulate fluorescein dianion which replace the hexafluorophosphate anion. Regarding fluorescein encapsulation, the cage in 1 increases its void size drastically (5 times) to fit the size of fluorescein, while the cages in 2 have no discernible changes after fluorescein encapsulation. This can be explained by size match between host metallocage and guest fluorescein.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of water. This solution was added to a 10 mL methanol solution containing L (31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 10 min and then filtered. The filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week. Colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. We washed the crystal with water and methanol. Yield: 67% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Zn: C, 48.39; H, 3.91; N, 18.81. Found: C, 48.44; H, 3.69; N, 18.93. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1501(m), 1440(m), 1278(s), 1210(m), 1123(s), 1020(m), 988(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 766(m), 678(m), 659(m), 557(m).

Synthesis of {[CoL<sub>3</sub>](PF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

An 8-mL aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.10 mmol) and NH4PF6 (32.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) were placed on the bottom of a glass tube. Five milliliters of 1:1 (V/V) acetone−water was carefully layered on top of the aqueous solution. Finally, 8 mL of acetone solution (contains 31.5 mg, 0.10 mmol of ligand) was layered. We carefully sealed the glass tube. Red-block crystal settled gradually after a month, and then it was filtered and washed with water and acetone. Yield: 46% based on ligand. Anal. calcd for C54H52F12N18O2P2Co: C, 48.62; H, 3.93; N, 18.90. Found: C, 48.94; H, 3.73; N, 18.96. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3438(br), 3158(m), 1523(s), 1499(m), 1440(m), 1277(s), 1210(m), 1121(s), 1022(m), 989(m), 840(vs), 792(m), 769(m), 679(m), 659(m), 557(m).

Fluorocein Encapsulation

Fluorescein encapsulations were investigated for samples before drying and after full vacuum dehydration at 120 °C overnight, respectively. Thus, 160 mg of fluorescein was suspended in 10 mL of water, 1 mol·L−1 KOH was added carefully to increase pH to 9 to dissolve fluorescein, corresponding to 0.05 mmol·L−1 fluorescein disodium. A crystal of 1 or 2 (∼200 mg) was added to the above solution and the mixture was allowed to stand at room temperature for a week with occasional shaking or stirring. The sample was filtrated off and washed with water and methanol. From weight gains, the encapsulations were estimated. {[ZnL3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [ZnL3]} n : C, 66.09; H, 4.35; N, 18.75. Found: C, 65.78; H, 4.49; N, 18.53. Calcd. Zn, 4.86%. Found: Zn, 4.97%. {[Co(L)3](fluorescein)}: Anal. calcd for {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n : C, 66.41; H, 4.37; N, 18.84. Found: C, 65.93; H, 4.45; N, 18.65. Calcd. Co, 4.37%. Found: Co, 4.43%.

cln_elements.content:
Crystal structure analysis gives 1 the formula of {[Zn(L)3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n . The formula agrees well with elemental analysis and thermogravimetric−differential scanning calorimetry (TG−DSC) analysis. The TG curve of the complex indicates that the complex framework is stable up to 265 °C. The 2.65% weight loss corresponds to two crystalline water molecules (2.69%) (). The IR spectrum shows a strong characteristic of PF6 − at 840 cm−1 (Figure ).

PXRD Pattern

PXRD of complex 1 indicate the crystallinity keeps well before and after drying and fluorescein encapsulation (Figure ). Drying significantly changes the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is quite common, but also quite different from that of the Co(II) complex (Figure ). The PXRD patterns of fluorescein encapsulated samples are similar whether 1 is vacuum-dried overnight or as-synthesized without any drying. The most intense absorption at 21.4° in 1 was shifted to a smaller 21.3°, while the intensity of weak peak at 20.6° was increased significantly after drying. A peak at 17.6° appeared after drying. After fluorescein encapsulation, the strongest peak shifted to 19.3°. These data indicate that crystal 1 changes its configuration after encapsulation of fluorescein.

Fluorescence Spectra

As shown in Figure , ligand and complex 1 both have an ∼430 emission peak when excited at 360 nm. The fluorescein encapsulated sample has a strong emission of 554 nm under identical experimental conditions. Free fluorescein dianion has a fluorescence peak at 514 nm (Figure ), which is identical to reported data in the solid state. We attribute the 554 nm fluorescence to fluorescein. The significant red-shift can be attributed the biphenyl moiety. The biphenyl moiety may have π−π interactions with the aromatic rings of fluorescein dianion which will decrease the energy level of fluorescein dianion. Complex 2 is paramagnetic and has no fluorescence as expected. After fluorescein adsorption, it has fluorescence emissions at 465 nm when excited at 435 nm (). The significant fluorescence difference between 1 and 2 is attributed to the paramagnetism and diamagnetism of metal ions. In UV light, {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n displays a bright color ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description of 1 

Crystal structure analysis gives 1 the formula of {[Zn(L)3](PF6)2(H2O)2} n . The formula agrees well with elemental analysis and thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) analysis. The TG curve of the complex indicates that the complex framework is stable up to 265 °C. The 2.65% weight loss corresponds to two crystalline water molecules (2.69%) (). The IR spectrum shows a strong characteristic of PF6 - at 840 cm-1 (Figure ).

PXRD Pattern

PXRD of complex 1 indicate the crystallinity keeps well before and after drying and fluorescein encapsulation (Figure ). Drying significantly changes the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which is quite common, but also quite different from that of the Co(II) complex (Figure ). The PXRD patterns of fluorescein encapsulated samples are similar whether 1 is vacuum-dried overnight or as-synthesized without any drying. The most intense absorption at 21.4° in 1 was shifted to a smaller 21.3°, while the intensity of weak peak at 20.6° was increased significantly after drying. A peak at 17.6° appeared after drying. After fluorescein encapsulation, the strongest peak shifted to 19.3°. These data indicate that crystal 1 changes its configuration after encapsulation of fluorescein.

Fluorescence Spectra

As shown in Figure , ligand and complex 1 both have an ~430 emission peak when excited at 360 nm. The fluorescein encapsulated sample has a strong emission of 554 nm under identical experimental conditions. Free fluorescein dianion has a fluorescence peak at 514 nm (Figure ), which is identical to reported data in the solid state. We attribute the 554 nm fluorescence to fluorescein. The significant red-shift can be attributed the biphenyl moiety. The biphenyl moiety may have π-π interactions with the aromatic rings of fluorescein dianion which will decrease the energy level of fluorescein dianion. Complex 2 is paramagnetic and has no fluorescence as expected. After fluorescein adsorption, it has fluorescence emissions at 465 nm when excited at 435 nm (). The significant fluorescence difference between 1 and 2 is attributed to the paramagnetism and diamagnetism of metal ions. In UV light, {C20H10O5 ⊂ [CoL3]} n  displays a bright color ().
